causes: Qing Dynasty sought to bring Taiwan under control after the defeat of the Dutch and Koxinga's resistance.
Koxinga's descendants controlled the Kingdom of Tungning and posed a challenge to Qing authority.
The Qing wanted to eliminate piracy and expand their maritime trade.
events_leading_up_to_war: After Koxinga's death, his son Zheng Keshuang ruled the Kingdom of Tungning but was in a precarious position.
Qing Dynasty forces, led by Admiral Shi Lang, were preparing to invade Taiwan and remove the remaining resistance.

result.territorial_changes: Taiwan became part of the Qing Empire, ending the kingdom of Tungning.

Kingdom_of_Tungning.weapons: Traditional infantry, cannons, and pirate vessels

major_battles.name: Battle of the Bay of Dajia
major_battles.description: A decisive naval battle where Qing forces destroyed the Tungning fleet, forcing the surrender of Zheng Keshuang.
major_battles.outcome: Qing victory, leading to the fall of the Kingdom of Tungning.

texts.name: Qing Annals
texts.details: Describes the campaigns and victories of Qing forces in Taiwan.

texts.name: Tungning Chronicles
texts.details: Document the kingdom's defense efforts and final surrender.

archaeological_evidence.description: Artifacts from Qing forces, including cannons and naval equipment found along Taiwan’s coastline.
Monuments and memorials erected in Taiwan commemorating the legacy of Koxinga and his descendants.

political: Taiwan was annexed by the Qing Empire and became part of the Fujian province.
The Zheng family’s rule over Taiwan was dismantled, and the island was opened up to Qing settlers.
long_term_effects: Qing rule over Taiwan would last until the late 19th century, shaping its future political structure.
The conquest marked the end of major Chinese resistance in the Taiwan Strait.

military: Marked the Qing's strategic control over the Taiwan Strait, helping to secure trade routes.
Signaled the end of powerful maritime resistance in the region.
political: Consolidated Qing control over an important maritime region and laid the groundwork for the island’s future integration into China.
Ended the last vestige of the Ming loyalist resistance in Taiwan.
cultural: Promoted Chinese settlement and agricultural development in Taiwan.
Led to the spread of Chinese culture and the integration of Taiwan into the Qing Empire’s broader sphere of influence.
